These Are The Fake Experts Pushing Pseudoscience And Conspiracy Theories About The Coronavirus Pandemic@CraigSilverman4/21/2020

A guide to the spin doctors and conspiracy theorists clogging up your social media feed.

5g, Artin Massihi, bill gates, Cameron Kyle-Sidell, coronavirus, covid, covid-19, Dan Erickson, David Icke, debunking, disinformation, epidemic, Eric Nepute, facebook, fact check, fake news, false, falsehood, grants, hoax, instagram, Judy Mikovits, Mark Steele, misinformation, pandemic, plandemic, Rashid Buttar, reddit, sars, Scott Jensen, Shiva Ayyadurai, snapchat, twitter, vimeo, whatsapp, youtube, USNewsArchivedRead

        function makeTCFStub() {
            var TCF_LOCATOR_NAME = '__tcfapiLocator';
            var queue = [];
            var win = window;
            var cmpFrame;
            function addFrame() {
                var doc = win.document;
                var otherCMP = !!win.frames[TCF_LOCATOR_NAME];
                if (!otherCMP) {
                    if (doc.body) {
                        var iframe = doc.createElement('iframe');
                        iframe.style.cssText = 'display:none';
                        iframe.name = TCF_LOCATOR_NAME;
                        doc.body.appendChild(iframe);
                    } else {
                        setTimeout(addFrame, 5);
                    }
                }
                return !otherCMP;
            }
            function tcfAPIHandler() {
                var gdprApplies;
                var args = arguments;
                if (!args.length) {
                    return queue;
                } else if (args[0] === 'setGdprApplies') {
                    if (args.length > 3 && args[2] === 2 && typeof args[3] === 'boolean') {
                        gdprApplies = args[3];
                        if (typeof args[2] === 'function') {
                            args[2]('set', true);
                        }
                    }
                } else if (args[0] === 'ping') {
                    var retr = {
                        gdprApplies: gdprApplies,
                        cmpLoaded: false,
                        cmpStatus: 'stub'
                    };
                    if (typeof args[2] === 'function') {
                        args[2](retr);
                    }
                } else {
                    queue.push(args);
                }
            }
            function postMessageEventHandler(event) {
                var msgIsString = typeof event.data === 'string';
                var json = {};
                try {
                    if (msgIsString) {
                        json = JSON.parse(event.data);
                    } else {
                        json = event.data;
                    }
                } catch (ignore) {}
                var payload = json.__tcfapiCall;
                if (payload) {
                    window.__tcfapi(payload.command, payload.version, function(retValue, success) {
                        var returnMsg = {
                            __tcfapiReturn: {
                                returnValue: retValue,
                                success: success,
                                callId: payload.callId
                            }
                        };
                        if (msgIsString) {
                            returnMsg = JSON.stringify(returnMsg);
                        }
                        event.source.postMessage(returnMsg, '*');
                    }, payload.parameter);
                }
            }
            while(win){
                try {
                    if (win.frames[TCF_LOCATOR_NAME]) {
                        cmpFrame = win;
                        break;
                    }
                } catch (ignore) {}
                if (win === window.top) {
                    break;
                }
                win = win.parent;
            }
            if (!cmpFrame) {
                addFrame();
                win.__tcfapi = tcfAPIHandler;
                win.addEventListener('message', postMessageEventHandler, false);
            }
        }

        };
        if (typeof window.__uspapi === 'undefined') {
            window.__uspapi = uspStubFunction;
        }
        // if a consuming service has defined stubs for `__tcfapi` and `__uspapi`,
        // but hasn't loaded the real CMP within a reasonable amount of time,
        // it indicates a problem that we want to surface in Sentry
        // (the problem being that calls to the APIs made by 3rd parties will be pending forever)
        var cmpLoadThreshold = 10000;
        // hack to avoid unnecessary transpilation of the stub code

        var Promise = window.Promise;

            new Promise(function(resolve) {

            }),
            new Promise(function(_, reject) {
                setTimeout(function() {
                    reject('__tcfapi stub is defined, but CMP has not loaded within ' + cmpLoadThreshold + 'ms');
                }, cmpLoadThreshold);
            }), 
        ]);

<p><b>Many of those</b> who spread hoaxes and pseudoscience about the <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/collection/coronavirus" target="_blank">coronavirus</a> pandemic can be hard to distinguish from medical authorities recognized by their peers as legitimate.<br /></p><p>To help you cut through the misinformation, we're keeping a running list of the most prominent people who have pushed what scientists and professional fact-checkers have found to be demonstrably false claims about the outbreak — and who they really are. We’re also highlighting real experts whose words were taken out of context and deliberately distorted.</p><h2>The Spin Doctors</h2>

<p><b>Name:</b> Judy Mikovits</p><p><b>Who she is</b>: Mikovits holds a PhD in biochemistry and molecular biology from George Washington University. She was formerly the research director at the Whittemore Peterson Institute. In 2012, Mikovits coauthored a controversial paper on chronic fatigue syndrome. Following its publication, the academic journal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/12/updated-rare-move-science-without-authors-consent-retracts-paper-tied-mouse-virus" target="_blank">Science retracted it</a> when the work of Mikovits and her colleagues could not be replicated. Before the retraction, Mikovits’ <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/10/chronic-fatigue-syndrome-researcher-fired-amidst-new-controversy" target="_blank">employer fired her</a>, saying it was unrelated to the controversy around the research. In a 2014 book Mikovits coauthored, she claimed that Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, had personally barred her from the NIH premises. In 2018, Fauci categorically denied that claim to the <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/scientist-vaccine-jailed/" target="_blank">fact-checking site Snopes</a>, saying, “I have no idea what she is talking about.” Since 2014, she has been <a rel="nofollow" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200511163228/http://www.autismone.org/search_videos?video_keywords=judy+mikovits" target="_blank">making appearances</a> at a conference dedicated to denying vaccine science and saying that autism and vaccinations are connected, which is <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/autism.html" target="_blank">false, according to the CDC</a>.</p><p><b>What she has said about the coronavirus</b>: In the video titled “<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/coronavirus-plandemic-viral-harmful-fauci-mikovits" target="_blank">Plandemic</a>,” she paints herself as a whistleblower, claiming the coronavirus pandemic was planned by shadowy global figures. Mikovits found an audience — it was shared, liked, and commented on over 20 million times on Facebook. In the video, Mikovits <a rel="nofollow" href="https://theconversation.com/masks-help-stop-the-spread-of-coronavirus-the-science-is-simple-and-im-one-of-100-experts-urging-governors-to-require-public-mask-wearing-138507" target="_blank">goes against scientific advice</a> and claims that wearing a mask could make someone sick, that sand and water from the beach can help cure the coronavirus, and that yet-uninvented vaccines for it could be dangerous. Mikovits also <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/05/08/plandemic-judy-mikovits-coronavirus/" target="_blank">misrepresents</a> her research and arrest, not mentioning that her study was retracted and claiming she was held in jail without charges.</p><p><b>What authorities have said</b>: In 2011, <a rel="nofollow" href="http://blogs.wsj.com/health/2011/10/03/scientist-who-led-xmrv-research-team-let-go/" target="_blank">Mikovits was fired</a> from the Whittemore Peterson Institute. Subsequently, the <a rel="nofollow" href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/326/5952/585.long" target="_blank">paper she coauthored was retracted</a>, after it was found that <a rel="nofollow" href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/334/6063/1636.1" target="_blank">samples were contaminated and other scientists, including those in her own lab, could not replicate the results</a>. After her firing, Mikovits <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/11/lawsuit-filed-against-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-researcher-former-employer" target="_blank">faced a lawsuit</a> from her former employer for allegedly <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/6884828-Ex-2-3-Warrant-Lacking-Signatures.html" target="_blank">stealing lab equipment and data</a>. She <a rel="nofollow" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111222184002/http://www.chicagotribune.com/health/ct-nw-chronic-fatigue-scientist-arrest-20111122,0,5455739.story" target="_blank">spent five days in jail</a> in California being held as a fugitive, after which the <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2012/06/criminal-charges-dropped-against-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-researcher-judy-mikovits" target="_blank">charges were dropped</a> in 2012. Mikovits <a rel="nofollow" href="https://retractionwatch.com/2015/11/16/chronic-fatigue-xmrv-researcher-heads-to-court-today-alleging-conspiracy-and-asking-for-750k/" target="_blank">filed a countersuit against her former employer</a> that was <a rel="nofollow" href="https://retractionwatch.com/2016/02/16/court-dismisses-lawsuit-by-xmrv-chronic-fatigue-researcher/" target="_blank">dismissed in 2016</a> in part because she did not provide the necessary documentation.</p>

<p><b>Name:</b> Shiva Ayyadurai</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> A candidate for the GOP nomination for Senate in Massachusetts, who dubiously <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/defamation-lawsuit-brought-self-proclaimed-email-inventor-settles-n1007196" target="_blank">claimed</a> to have invented email. He also dated, and reportedly <a rel="nofollow" href="https://people.com/celebrity/fran-drescher-marries-shiva-ayyadurai/" target="_blank">married</a>, actor Fran Drescher. In 2018, during a previous Senate bid, the city of Cambridge, Massachusetts, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.necn.com/news/national-international/sen-warrens-challenger-ends-lawsuit-over-fake-indian-sign/2022959/" target="_blank">ordered</a> him to remove a sign from his campaign bus that read "Only a REAL INDIAN Can Defeat the Fake Indian," referencing Sen. Elizabeth Warren. Ayyadurai sued, and the city backed down.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> Ayyadurai accused Fauci of ties to Big Pharma without evidence, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/13/anti-vaccine-activists-fire-fauci-furor-185001" target="_blank">according to Politico</a>, and called for him to be fired. He defined COVID-19 as “an overactive dysfunctional immune system that overreacts and that's what causes damage to the body," which is <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/youtube-anthony-fauci-deep-state-coronavirus" target="_blank">not accurate, according to medical experts</a>. Ayyadurai has also <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/youtube-anthony-fauci-deep-state-coronavirus" target="_blank">claimed</a> that vitamin C could be used to treat the disease, which is not true, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/myth-busters" target="_blank">according to the World Health Organization</a>.</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> Ayyadurai claims to have created an email program while in high school in the ‘70s and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.inventorofemail.com/" target="_blank">labeled himself</a> “the inventor of email,” but that claim has been disputed by experts. Technology historian Thomas Haigh <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190518/23370542236/laying-out-all-evidence-shiva-ayyadurai-did-not-invent-email.shtml" target="_blank">wrote</a> that Ayyadurai "did not invent email. [...] The details of Ayyadurai’s program were never published, it was never commercialized, and it had no apparent influence on any further work in the field." In 2017, a judge <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/09/07/email_inventor_has_libel_lawsuit_tossed/" target="_blank">dismissed</a> a libel suit Ayyadurai brought over a <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190516/22284042229/our-legal-dispute-with-shiva-ayyadurai-is-now-over.shtml" target="_blank">Techdirt story</a> that stated he did not invent email. Ayyadurai appealed that dismissal, and in 2019 Techdirt agreed to settle the case that meant that the news organization had to link to <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.inventorofemail.com/Shiva-Ayyadurai.asp" target="_blank">Ayyadurai’s claim</a> of him inventing email on its stories about him.</p>

<p><b>Name:</b> Eric Nepute</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> A chiropractor with a degree from Logan University and accredited by the state of Missouri.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> In a Facebook Live video viewed 2.1 million times, Nepute <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/chiropractors-misinformation-coronavirus" target="_blank">urged</a> people to drink quinine and eat zinc to fight COVID-19. He also <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.facebook.com/1429618713952936/videos/598152767455055" target="_blank">filmed a video</a> with Sherri Tenpenny, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/health-and-wellness/questions-that-need-to-be-asked-pete-evans-endorses-anti-vaxxer-20190314-p5144h.html" target="_blank">who speaks against vaccine science</a>, claiming the development of a COVID-19 vaccine was a plot to encourage mandatory vaccinations.</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> As <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.snopes.com/news/2020/04/15/real-doctor-tonic-water/" target="_blank">Snopes pointed out</a>, he made pseudoscientific claims, including about the health benefits of tonic water: "You would need to drink more than 12 liters of Schweppes tonic water every eight hours to maintain those therapeutic levels of quinine (usually provided in pill form) from tonic water." In addition, Nepute claimed that quinine worked "similar-ish" to chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, the compounds under study as potential treatments for COVID-19, a claim which <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.snopes.com/news/2020/04/15/real-doctor-tonic-water/" target="_blank">Snopes reported</a> was inaccurate. The year before the pandemic, the Better Business Bureau challenged an advertising claim on Nepute's website, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.bbb.org/us/mo/saint-louis/profile/chiropractors-dc/nepute-wellness-center-0734-310344009/details#all-alerts" target="_blank">which stated</a>, “Our ideal circumstance is what we call Preconception Care. This is when parents come to us at least 2 years before conceiving a child to first correct unidentified health issues with them in order to prevent those genes from being passed down.” According to the BBB, Nepute’s office initially replied but “did not respond to BBB’s request for substantiation/documentation.”</p>

<p><b>Name:</b> Rashid Buttar</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> An osteopath who <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.drbuttar.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/DRBUTTAR-CV-c.pdf" target="_blank">earned his degree</a> from Des Moines University. In 2009, Buttar claimed to have treated a young woman who <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.columbianeurosurgery.org/news/team-approach-and-correct-diagnosis-are-key-in-treatment-of-dystonia/" target="_blank">said she got dystonia and was unable to speak after receiving a flu vaccine</a>. News reports at the time challenged the story, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://abcnews.go.com/2020/desiree-jennings-fake-muscle-disorder/story?id=11228285" target="_blank">according to ABC News</a>. Buttar has been a proponent of <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.webmd.com/balance/guide/what-is-chelation-therapy#1" target="_blank">chelation therapy</a> as a treatment for various illnesses and disorders, including autism, which involves administering IV or pills that bind to metals in a patient's blood. Other than as a treatment for lead or mercury poisoning, the Mayo Clinic <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-disease/expert-answers/chelation-therapy/faq-20157449" target="_blank">does not recommend chelation therapy</a>. Buttar has long spoken against vaccines and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170830115116/http://www.autismone.org/conferencevideos?page=5&autismone_confvideo_block_tab=4&referer=conferencevideos&args=" target="_blank">previously participated in a conference</a> in which speakers linked autism to vaccinations, a <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/autism.html" target="_blank">claim for which the CDC has said</a> there is no scientific evidence.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> Buttar has made claims <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.snopes.com/?s=Rashid+Buttar+" target="_blank">disputed by fact-checkers</a> regarding the coronavirus, including that <a rel="nofollow" href="https://factcheck.afp.com/flu-shot-will-not-make-you-test-positive-covid-19" target="_blank">receiving a flu shot</a> was tied to testing positive. Buttar <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/entry/coronavirus-conspiracy-theories-social-media_n_5e83d701c5b6a1bb764f6d3b?ri18n=true" target="_blank">also claimed</a> that the coronavirus was a biological weapon. (A <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-020-0820-9" target="_blank">paper in the scientific journal Nature</a> said the virus was “not a laboratory construct.”) Buttar <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/fauci-wuhan-funding-conspiracy" target="_blank">called for Dr. Fauci to be jailed</a> over a series of grants that were awarded after the 2003 SARS outbreak.</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> In 2010, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/local/medical-board-reprimands-mecklenburg-doctor-of-osteopathy/275-374414498" target="_blank">the North Carolina medical board reprimanded him</a> for, among other complaints, treating three cancer patients with therapies that had “no known value for the treatment of cancer,” documents from the case said. According to a <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/local/medical-board-reprimands-mecklenburg-doctor-of-osteopathy/275-374414498" target="_blank">WCNC report at the time,</a> “Buttar has spent years selling skin drops at $150 a bottle as a treatment for diseases ranging from autism to cancer.” In 2013, the FDA <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/investigations/2018/08/16/doctors-warned-fda-but-state-medical-boards-state-boards-fail-act/963651002/" target="_blank">sent Buttar a</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://quackwatch.org/cases/fdawarning/prod/fda-warning-letters-about-products-2013/buttar/" target="_blank">warning letter</a> for promoting and distributing unapproved medical products on his websites and YouTube videos. "The medical board and FDA have a responsibility to make sure doctors don't push too close to the edge," Buttar <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/fauci-wuhan-funding-conspiracy" target="_blank">previously said</a> in an emailed statement to BuzzFeed News. "The regulatory bodies serve an important function and are needed to safeguard the public."</p>

<p><b>Name:</b> Dr. Artin Massihi</p><p><b>Who he is</b>: The co-owner of Accelerated Urgent Care, a private clinic in Bakersfield, California.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> Massihi and his partner, Dr. Dan Erickson, called a press conference on April 22 to share data they claimed showed that the lockdowns should end, that COVID-19 was less deadly than commonly thought, and that physicians were being pressured to list COVID-19 as the cause of death for patients who had not tested positive. Public health authorities and a wide range of experts in the relevant fields <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/04/28/cue-the-debunking-two-bakersfield-doctors-go-viral-with-dubious-covid-test-conclusions/" target="_blank">condemned their data and conclusions as deeply flawed</a>, the Mercury News reported.</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> Massihi’s comments about COVID-19 were condemned <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.aaem.org/resources/statements/joint-endorsed/physician-misinformation" target="_blank">in a joint statement</a> by the American College of Emergency Physicians and the American Academy of Emergency Medicine as “reckless and untested musings” that were “inconsistent with current science and epidemiology regarding COVID-19.”</p>

<p><b>Name:</b> Dr. Dan Erickson</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> A former emergency room physician who co-owns Accelerated Urgent Care, a private clinic in Bakersfield, California.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> At the press conference Erickson made a statistical error when he said, “California is 12% positive. <p><b>Name:</b> David Icke</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> Formerly a soccer player, sports broadcaster, and spokesperson for the UK Green Party, Icke is known for conspiracy theories that the Center for Countering Digital Hate <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/icke-antisemitic-conspiracies-viewed-over-30-million-times-new-research-shows-1.499368" target="_blank">has called anti-Semitic</a>. He has suggested that interdimensional reptilian beings secretly control the world, that the moon <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/news/prize-winning-author-alice-walker-gives-support-to-david-icke-on-desert-island-discs-8622648.html" target="_blank">is a spacecraft</a>, and that the 9/11 attacks <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HkwgAxh5h_A" target="_blank">were not carried out by al-Qaeda, but by Israel</a>. He also claimed to be the "<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/only-in-britain/david-icke-terry-wogan-interview/" target="_blank">son of God</a>."<br /><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> Icke has inaccurately <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52501453" target="_blank">claimed</a> that Jews were behind the coronavirus, according to the BBC, and has <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/conspiracy-theory-5g-coronavirus-qanon" target="_blank">promoted</a> the conspiracy theory that 5G technology causes COVID-19. Following these claims, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52501453" target="_blank">Facebook</a> and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.newsweek.com/david-icke-man-behind-coronavirus-5g-conspiracy-has-youtube-channel-shuttered-sharing-1501641" target="_blank">YouTube</a> suspended Icke’s pages. Spotify <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/06/apple-spotify-david-icke-podcast.html" target="_blank">removed</a> a podcast episode featuring an interview with Icke in which he doubted the existence of the virus.</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> In 2017, the nonprofit Political Research Associates <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.politicalresearch.org/press/canadian-jewish-news-anti-semitic-conspiracy-theorist-david-icke-gives-talk-vancouver" target="_blank">described</a> Icke’s work as “a mishmash of most of the dominant themes of contemporary neofascism, mixed in with a smattering of topics culled from the U.S. militia movement.” In 2018, Jonathan Greenblatt, chief executive of the Anti-Defamation League, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/21/arts/alice-walker-david-icke-times.html?login=smartlock&auth=login-smartlock" target="_blank">said of Icke</a>, “There is no fair reading of Icke’s work that could be seen as not anti-Semitic.” UK media regulator Ofcom <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2020/apr/20/tv-stations-interview-with-david-icke-posed-threat-to-public-health" target="_blank">ruled last month</a> that a London Live TV segment with Icke “posed threat to public health.” The Center for Countering Digital Hate <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.counterhate.co.uk/icke" target="_blank">has called on</a> all major social media companies to deplatform Icke. After Facebook removed his official page, Icke <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52501453" target="_blank">tweeted</a>, "Fascist Facebook deletes David Icke - the elite are TERRIFIED."</p>

<p><b>Name:</b> Mark Steele</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> Steele claims in videos and at conferences that he is a weapons expert. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/wxeb45/my-dad-got-hoaxed-by-the-anti-5g-conspiracy-movement" target="_blank">According to Vice,</a> he works at Reevu, a UK-based firm that designs motorcycle helmets. Since 2018, Steele has harassed the town council of Gateshead, England, about 5G technology, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/gateshead-council-5g-mark-steele-15319350" target="_blank">according to Chronicle Live</a>. The council published a <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/gateshead-council-5g-street-lights-14510320" target="_blank">Facebook post</a> in 2018 denying it used 5G technology and rebuffing his other claims, like that street lights in town caused cancer.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> Steele claimed that 5G cellular technology causes COVID-19, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/coronavirus-5g-conspiracy-profit" target="_blank">calling</a> the disease a “genocide" carried by “the deep state.” An electrical engineer and a virologist <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/04/23/fact-check-5-g-technology-not-linked-coronavirus/3006152001/" target="_blank">told USA Today</a> that 5G and the coronavirus are not linked. Steele also gave a speech about 5G at a 2018 conference for the Democrats and Veterans Party, an offshoot of the British far-right political party UKIP, that was featured prominently in a now-deleted <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ChS3J893rpI" target="_blank">viral video</a>.</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> In 2018, a British court <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/5g-campaigner-trial-live-updates-15315540" target="_blank">convicted him</a> for threatening two councilors in Gateshead. Steele is currently under an <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.gateshead.gov.uk/article/9699/Injunction-obtained-against-Gateshead-resident" target="_blank">injunction</a> to prevent him from harassing or threatening the town's councilors or staff but <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/mark-steele-5g-gateshead-council-15269240" target="_blank">was allowed by the judge</a> to continue speaking against 5G. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/mark-steele-5g-gateshead-council-15269240" target="_blank">According to Chronicle Live</a>, Steele denied that he was harassing council members, saying he "acted proportionally."</p><h2><b>The Misquoted</b></h2>

<p><b>Name:</b> Sen. Scott Jensen</p><p><b>Who he is:</b> Jensen is a longtime family physician in Minnesota and a Republican member of the Minnesota Senate, who was elected in 2016. He is not seeking reelection in 2020 and is rumored to be interested in a run for governor.</p><p><b>What he has said about the virus:</b> On April 7, he gave a North Dakota TV <a rel="nofollow" href="https://twitter.com/chrisbergpov/status/1247680994821509121" target="_blank">interview</a> in which he suggested that hospitals and physicians were being told by the CDC to list COVID-19 as the cause of death in cases where it might not be warranted. His comment that “Fear is a great way to control people” was picked up by InfoWars and QAnon supporters. He later appeared on Fox News and said hospitals get paid more if a patient is listed as having COVID-19 and is on a ventilator, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/04/24/fact-check-medicare-hospitals-paid-more-covid-19-patients-coronavirus/3000638001/" target="_blank">which is true</a>. He did not directly say hospitals are doing this for the money, just that it’s a concern. His TV appearances were used in the “Plandemic” video, but he disavows virus conspiracies. "I think that things are being taken out of context,” he <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.startribune.com/as-minnesota-senator-cast-doubt-on-covid-19-death-tolls-conspiracy-theorists-pounced-online/569785662/?refresh=true" target="_blank">told</a> the Star Tribune.</p><p><b>What authorities have said</b>: Jensen is a physician in good standing.</p>

<p><b>Name</b>: Dr. Cameron Kyle-Sidell</p><p><b>Who he is</b>: Kyle-Sidell is an emergency and critical care physician at Maimonides hospital in Brooklyn. In March and April, he worked in an intensive care unit dedicated to COVID-19 patients. He received his medical degree from Ben Gurion University of the Negev in Israel.</p><p><b>What he has said about the coronavirus:</b> In a March 31 <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k9GYTc53r2o" target="_blank">YouTube video</a>, he questioned whether putting COVID-19 patients on ventilators was the right protocol and worried that this “misguided treatment will lead to a tremendous amount of harm to a great number of people in a very short time.” Since he raised the issue, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-ventilators-specia/special-report-as-virus-advances-doctors-rethink-rush-to-ventilate-idUSKCN2251PE" target="_blank">other physicians have shared similar views</a>. But his opinion has been misstated by conspiracy theorists to imply that the virus is not what the medical establishment says it is. On May 10, he <a rel="nofollow" href="https://twitter.com/cameronks/status/1259466360691752961" target="_blank">tweeted</a> that he had not consented to being included in “Plandemic,” saying, “I do not believe the narrative underlying the origin or spread of this terrible disease is one of human ill intent. We are fighting a virus not each other.”</p><p><b>What authorities have said:</b> Kyle-Sidell is a doctor in good standing and his inclusion in “Plandemic” and other fringe narratives is the result of people misinterpreting or exaggerating his comments.</p>

3]\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eBuzzFeed News has reporters across five continents bringing you trustworthy stories about the impact of the coronavirus. To help keep this news free,\u003c/i\u003e \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://support.buzzfeednews.com/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\u003ci\u003ebecome a member\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ci\u003eand sign up for our newsletter,\u003c/i\u003e \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeed.com/newsletters/coronavirus?utm_source=newsletter\"\u003eOutbreak Today\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 1]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eMany of those\u003c/b\u003e who spread hoaxes and pseudoscience about the \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/collection/coronavirus\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ecoronavirus\u003c/a\u003e pandemic can be hard to distinguish from medical authorities recognized by their peers as legitimate.\u003cbr /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eTo help you cut through the misinformation, we're keeping a running list of the most prominent people who have pushed what scientists and professional fact-checkers have found to be demonstrably false claims about the outbreak — and who they really are. We’re also highlighting real experts whose words were taken out of context and deliberately distorted.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eThe Spin Doctors\u003c/h2\u003e[INSERT 14][INSERT 4]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Judy Mikovits\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho she is\u003c/b\u003e: Mikovits holds a PhD in biochemistry and molecular biology from George Washington University. She was formerly the research director at the Whittemore Peterson Institute. In 2012, Mikovits coauthored a controversial paper on chronic fatigue syndrome. Following its publication, the academic journal \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/12/updated-rare-move-science-without-authors-consent-retracts-paper-tied-mouse-virus\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eScience retracted it\u003c/a\u003e when the work of Mikovits and her colleagues could not be replicated. Before the retraction, Mikovits’ \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/10/chronic-fatigue-syndrome-researcher-fired-amidst-new-controversy\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eemployer fired her\u003c/a\u003e, saying it was unrelated to the controversy around the research. In a 2014 book Mikovits coauthored, she claimed that Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, had personally barred her from the NIH premises. In 2018, Fauci categorically denied that claim to the \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/scientist-vaccine-jailed/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003efact-checking site Snopes\u003c/a\u003e, saying, “I have no idea what she is talking about.” Since 2014, she has been \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20200511163228/http://www.autismone.org/search_videos?video_keywords=judy+mikovits\" target=\"_blank\"\u003emaking appearances\u003c/a\u003e at a conference dedicated to denying vaccine science and saying that autism and vaccinations are connected, which is \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/autism.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003efalse, according to the CDC\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat she has said about the coronavirus\u003c/b\u003e: In the video titled “\u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/coronavirus-plandemic-viral-harmful-fauci-mikovits\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ePlandemic\u003c/a\u003e,” she paints herself as a whistleblower, claiming the coronavirus pandemic was planned by shadowy global figures. Mikovits found an audience — it was shared, liked, and commented on over 20 million times on Facebook. In the video, Mikovits \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://theconversation.com/masks-help-stop-the-spread-of-coronavirus-the-science-is-simple-and-im-one-of-100-experts-urging-governors-to-require-public-mask-wearing-138507\" target=\"_blank\"\u003egoes against scientific advice\u003c/a\u003e and claims that wearing a mask could make someone sick, that sand and water from the beach can help cure the coronavirus, and that yet-uninvented vaccines for it could be dangerous. Mikovits also \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/05/08/plandemic-judy-mikovits-coronavirus/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003emisrepresents\u003c/a\u003e her research and arrest, not mentioning that her study was retracted and claiming she was held in jail without charges.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said\u003c/b\u003e: In 2011, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"http://blogs.wsj.com/health/2011/10/03/scientist-who-led-xmrv-research-team-let-go/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eMikovits was fired\u003c/a\u003e from the Whittemore Peterson Institute. Subsequently, the \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://science.sciencemag.org/content/326/5952/585.long\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epaper she coauthored was retracted\u003c/a\u003e, after it was found that \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://science.sciencemag.org/content/334/6063/1636.1\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esamples were contaminated and other scientists, including those in her own lab, could not replicate the results\u003c/a\u003e. After her firing, Mikovits \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2011/11/lawsuit-filed-against-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-researcher-former-employer\" target=\"_blank\"\u003efaced a lawsuit\u003c/a\u003e from her former employer for allegedly \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/6884828-Ex-2-3-Warrant-Lacking-Signatures.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003estealing lab equipment and data\u003c/a\u003e. She \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20111222184002/http://www.chicagotribune.com/health/ct-nw-chronic-fatigue-scientist-arrest-20111122,0,5455739.story\" target=\"_blank\"\u003espent five days in jail\u003c/a\u003e in California being held as a fugitive, after which the \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2012/06/criminal-charges-dropped-against-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-researcher-judy-mikovits\" target=\"_blank\"\u003echarges were dropped\u003c/a\u003e in 2012. Mikovits \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://retractionwatch.com/2015/11/16/chronic-fatigue-xmrv-researcher-heads-to-court-today-alleging-conspiracy-and-asking-for-750k/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003efiled a countersuit against her former employer\u003c/a\u003e that was \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://retractionwatch.com/2016/02/16/court-dismisses-lawsuit-by-xmrv-chronic-fatigue-researcher/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003edismissed in 2016\u003c/a\u003e in part because she did not provide the necessary documentation.\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 5]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Shiva Ayyadurai\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e A candidate for the GOP nomination for Senate in Massachusetts, who dubiously \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/defamation-lawsuit-brought-self-proclaimed-email-inventor-settles-n1007196\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eclaimed\u003c/a\u003e to have invented email. He also dated, and reportedly \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://people.com/celebrity/fran-drescher-marries-shiva-ayyadurai/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003emarried\u003c/a\u003e, actor Fran Drescher. In 2018, during a previous Senate bid, the city of Cambridge, Massachusetts, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.necn.com/news/national-international/sen-warrens-challenger-ends-lawsuit-over-fake-indian-sign/2022959/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eordered\u003c/a\u003e him to remove a sign from his campaign bus that read \"Only a REAL INDIAN Can Defeat the Fake Indian,\" referencing Sen. Elizabeth Warren. Ayyadurai sued, and the city backed down.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e Ayyadurai accused Fauci of ties to Big Pharma without evidence, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/13/anti-vaccine-activists-fire-fauci-furor-185001\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eaccording to Politico\u003c/a\u003e, and called for him to be fired. He defined COVID-19 as “an overactive dysfunctional immune system that overreacts and that's what causes damage to the body,\" which is \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/youtube-anthony-fauci-deep-state-coronavirus\" target=\"_blank\"\u003enot accurate, according to medical experts\u003c/a\u003e. Ayyadurai has also \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/youtube-anthony-fauci-deep-state-coronavirus\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eclaimed\u003c/a\u003e that vitamin C could be used to treat the disease, which is not true, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/myth-busters\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eaccording to the World Health Organization\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e Ayyadurai claims to have created an email program while in high school in the ‘70s and \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.inventorofemail.com/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003elabeled himself\u003c/a\u003e “the inventor of email,” but that claim has been disputed by experts. Technology historian Thomas Haigh \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190518/23370542236/laying-out-all-evidence-shiva-ayyadurai-did-not-invent-email.shtml\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e that Ayyadurai \"did not invent email. [...] The details of Ayyadurai’s program were never published, it was never commercialized, and it had no apparent influence on any further work in the field.\" In 2017, a judge \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/09/07/email_inventor_has_libel_lawsuit_tossed/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003edismissed\u003c/a\u003e a libel suit Ayyadurai brought over a \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20190516/22284042229/our-legal-dispute-with-shiva-ayyadurai-is-now-over.shtml\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eTechdirt story\u003c/a\u003e that stated he did not invent email. Ayyadurai appealed that dismissal, and in 2019 Techdirt agreed to settle the case that meant that the news organization had to link to \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.inventorofemail.com/Shiva-Ayyadurai.asp\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eAyyadurai’s claim\u003c/a\u003e of him inventing email on its stories about him.\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 6]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Eric Nepute\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e A chiropractor with a degree from Logan University and accredited by the state of Missouri.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e In a Facebook Live video viewed 2.1 million times, Nepute \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/chiropractors-misinformation-coronavirus\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eurged\u003c/a\u003e people to drink quinine and eat zinc to fight COVID-19. He also \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/1429618713952936/videos/598152767455055\" target=\"_blank\"\u003efilmed a video\u003c/a\u003e with Sherri Tenpenny, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/health-and-wellness/questions-that-need-to-be-asked-pete-evans-endorses-anti-vaxxer-20190314-p5144h.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewho speaks against vaccine science\u003c/a\u003e, claiming the development of a COVID-19 vaccine was a plot to encourage mandatory vaccinations.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e As \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.snopes.com/news/2020/04/15/real-doctor-tonic-water/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSnopes pointed out\u003c/a\u003e, he made pseudoscientific claims, including about the health benefits of tonic water: \"You would need to drink more than 12 liters of Schweppes tonic water every eight hours to maintain those therapeutic levels of quinine (usually provided in pill form) from tonic water.\" In addition, Nepute claimed that quinine worked \"similar-ish\" to chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, the compounds under study as potential treatments for COVID-19, a claim which \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.snopes.com/news/2020/04/15/real-doctor-tonic-water/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSnopes reported\u003c/a\u003e was inaccurate. The year before the pandemic, the Better Business Bureau challenged an advertising claim on Nepute's website, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.bbb.org/us/mo/saint-louis/profile/chiropractors-dc/nepute-wellness-center-0734-310344009/details#all-alerts\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewhich stated\u003c/a\u003e, “Our ideal circumstance is what we call Preconception Care. This is when parents come to us at least 2 years before conceiving a child to first correct unidentified health issues with them in order to prevent those genes from being passed down.” According to the BBB, Nepute’s office initially replied but “did not respond to BBB’s request for substantiation/documentation.”\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 7]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Rashid Buttar\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e An osteopath who \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.drbuttar.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/DRBUTTAR-CV-c.pdf\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eearned his degree\u003c/a\u003e from Des Moines University. In 2009, Buttar claimed to have treated a young woman who \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.columbianeurosurgery.org/news/team-approach-and-correct-diagnosis-are-key-in-treatment-of-dystonia/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esaid she got dystonia and was unable to speak after receiving a flu vaccine\u003c/a\u003e. News reports at the time challenged the story, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/2020/desiree-jennings-fake-muscle-disorder/story?id=11228285\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eaccording to ABC News\u003c/a\u003e. Buttar has been a proponent of \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.webmd.com/balance/guide/what-is-chelation-therapy#1\" target=\"_blank\"\u003echelation therapy\u003c/a\u003e as a treatment for various illnesses and disorders, including autism, which involves administering IV or pills that bind to metals in a patient's blood. Other than as a treatment for lead or mercury poisoning, the Mayo Clinic \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-disease/expert-answers/chelation-therapy/faq-20157449\" target=\"_blank\"\u003edoes not recommend chelation therapy\u003c/a\u003e. Buttar has long spoken against vaccines and \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20170830115116/http://www.autismone.org/conferencevideos?page=5\u0026autismone_confvideo_block_tab=4\u0026referer=conferencevideos\u0026args=\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epreviously participated in a conference\u003c/a\u003e in which speakers linked autism to vaccinations, a \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/autism.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eclaim for which the CDC has said\u003c/a\u003e there is no scientific evidence.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e Buttar has made claims \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.snopes.com/?s=Rashid+Buttar+\" target=\"_blank\"\u003edisputed by fact-checkers\u003c/a\u003e regarding the coronavirus, including that \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://factcheck.afp.com/flu-shot-will-not-make-you-test-positive-covid-19\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ereceiving a flu shot\u003c/a\u003e was tied to testing positive. Buttar \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/entry/coronavirus-conspiracy-theories-social-media_n_5e83d701c5b6a1bb764f6d3b?ri18n=true\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ealso claimed\u003c/a\u003e that the coronavirus was a biological weapon. (A \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-020-0820-9\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epaper in the scientific journal Nature\u003c/a\u003e said the virus was “not a laboratory construct.”) Buttar \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/fauci-wuhan-funding-conspiracy\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ecalled for Dr. Fauci to be jailed\u003c/a\u003e over a series of grants that were awarded after the 2003 SARS outbreak.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e In 2010, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/local/medical-board-reprimands-mecklenburg-doctor-of-osteopathy/275-374414498\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ethe North Carolina medical board reprimanded him\u003c/a\u003e for, among other complaints, treating three cancer patients with therapies that had “no known value for the treatment of cancer,” documents from the case said. According to a \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/local/medical-board-reprimands-mecklenburg-doctor-of-osteopathy/275-374414498\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eWCNC report at the time,\u003c/a\u003e “Buttar has spent years selling skin drops at $150 a bottle as a treatment for diseases ranging from autism to cancer.” In 2013, the FDA \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/investigations/2018/08/16/doctors-warned-fda-but-state-medical-boards-state-boards-fail-act/963651002/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esent Buttar a\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://quackwatch.org/cases/fdawarning/prod/fda-warning-letters-about-products-2013/buttar/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewarning letter\u003c/a\u003e for promoting and distributing unapproved medical products on his websites and YouTube videos. \"The medical board and FDA have a responsibility to make sure doctors don't push too close to the edge,\" Buttar \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/janelytvynenko/fauci-wuhan-funding-conspiracy\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epreviously said\u003c/a\u003e in an emailed statement to BuzzFeed News. \"The regulatory bodies serve an important function and are needed to safeguard the public.\"\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 8]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Dr. Artin Massihi\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is\u003c/b\u003e: The co-owner of Accelerated Urgent Care, a private clinic in Bakersfield, California.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e Massihi and his partner, Dr. Dan Erickson, called a press conference on April 22 to share data they claimed showed that the lockdowns should end, that COVID-19 was less deadly than commonly thought, and that physicians were being pressured to list COVID-19 as the cause of death for patients who had not tested positive. Public health authorities and a wide range of experts in the relevant fields \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/04/28/cue-the-debunking-two-bakersfield-doctors-go-viral-with-dubious-covid-test-conclusions/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003econdemned their data and conclusions as deeply flawed\u003c/a\u003e, the Mercury News reported.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e Massihi’s comments about COVID-19 were condemned \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.aaem.org/resources/statements/joint-endorsed/physician-misinformation\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ein a joint statement\u003c/a\u003e by the American College of Emergency Physicians and the American Academy of Emergency Medicine as “reckless and untested musings” that were “inconsistent with current science and epidemiology regarding COVID-19.”\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 9]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Dr. Dan Erickson\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e A former emergency room physician who co-owns Accelerated Urgent Care, a private clinic in Bakersfield, California.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e At the press conference Erickson made a statistical error when he said, “California is 12% positive. We have 39.5 million people. If we just take a basic calculation and just extrapolate that out, that equates to about 4.7 million cases throughout the state of California.” In fact, 12% of Californians who’d been \u003ci\u003etested\u003c/i\u003e were positive — a difference that undercuts his claim, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.bakersfield.com/news/local-doctors-assertions-on-covid-19-make-waves-on-social-media-attract-national-attention/article_6823a2e2-88a2-11ea-b44b-db257407c86b.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eaccording to public health professor\u003c/a\u003e Andrew Noymer.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e Kern Public Health, the local health authority, also \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/public-health-responds-to-claims-from-doctors-at-accelerated-urgent-care\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e Erickson was wrong when he claimed its top doctor agreed with him about the need to end the lockdowns.\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003e\u003cb\u003eThe 5G Conspiracy Theorists\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e[INSERT 16][INSERT 10]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e David Icke\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e Formerly a soccer player, sports broadcaster, and spokesperson for the UK Green Party, Icke is known for conspiracy theories that the Center for Countering Digital Hate \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/icke-antisemitic-conspiracies-viewed-over-30-million-times-new-research-shows-1.499368\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ehas called anti-Semitic\u003c/a\u003e. He has suggested that interdimensional reptilian beings secretly control the world, that the moon \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/news/prize-winning-author-alice-walker-gives-support-to-david-icke-on-desert-island-discs-8622648.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eis a spacecraft\u003c/a\u003e, and that the 9/11 attacks \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HkwgAxh5h_A\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewere not carried out by al-Qaeda, but by Israel\u003c/a\u003e. He also claimed to be the \"\u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/only-in-britain/david-icke-terry-wogan-interview/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eson of God\u003c/a\u003e.\"\u003cbr /\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e Icke has inaccurately \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52501453\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eclaimed\u003c/a\u003e that Jews were behind the coronavirus, according to the BBC, and has \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/conspiracy-theory-5g-coronavirus-qanon\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epromoted\u003c/a\u003e the conspiracy theory that 5G technology causes COVID-19. Following these claims, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52501453\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eFacebook\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.newsweek.com/david-icke-man-behind-coronavirus-5g-conspiracy-has-youtube-channel-shuttered-sharing-1501641\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eYouTube\u003c/a\u003e suspended Icke’s pages. Spotify \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/06/apple-spotify-david-icke-podcast.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eremoved\u003c/a\u003e a podcast episode featuring an interview with Icke in which he doubted the existence of the virus.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e In 2017, the nonprofit Political Research Associates \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.politicalresearch.org/press/canadian-jewish-news-anti-semitic-conspiracy-theorist-david-icke-gives-talk-vancouver\" target=\"_blank\"\u003edescribed\u003c/a\u003e Icke’s work as “a mishmash of most of the dominant themes of contemporary neofascism, mixed in with a smattering of topics culled from the U.S. militia movement.” In 2018, Jonathan Greenblatt, chief executive of the Anti-Defamation League, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/21/arts/alice-walker-david-icke-times.html?login=smartlock\u0026auth=login-smartlock\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esaid of Icke\u003c/a\u003e, “There is no fair reading of Icke’s work that could be seen as not anti-Semitic.” UK media regulator Ofcom \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2020/apr/20/tv-stations-interview-with-david-icke-posed-threat-to-public-health\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eruled last month\u003c/a\u003e that a London Live TV segment with Icke “posed threat to public health.” The Center for Countering Digital Hate \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.counterhate.co.uk/icke\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ehas called on\u003c/a\u003e all major social media companies to deplatform Icke. After Facebook removed his official page, Icke \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-52501453\" target=\"_blank\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e, \"Fascist Facebook deletes David Icke - the elite are TERRIFIED.\"\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 11]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Mark Steele\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e Steele claims in videos and at conferences that he is a weapons expert. \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/wxeb45/my-dad-got-hoaxed-by-the-anti-5g-conspiracy-movement\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eAccording to Vice,\u003c/a\u003e he works at Reevu, a UK-based firm that designs motorcycle helmets. Since 2018, Steele has harassed the town council of Gateshead, England, about 5G technology, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/gateshead-council-5g-mark-steele-15319350\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eaccording to Chronicle Live\u003c/a\u003e. The council published a \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/gateshead-council-5g-street-lights-14510320\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eFacebook post\u003c/a\u003e in 2018 denying it used 5G technology and rebuffing his other claims, like that street lights in town caused cancer.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e Steele claimed that 5G cellular technology causes COVID-19, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/coronavirus-5g-conspiracy-profit\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ecalling\u003c/a\u003e the disease a “genocide\" carried by “the deep state.” An electrical engineer and a virologist \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/04/23/fact-check-5-g-technology-not-linked-coronavirus/3006152001/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003etold USA Today\u003c/a\u003e that 5G and the coronavirus are not linked. Steele also gave a speech about 5G at a 2018 conference for the Democrats and Veterans Party, an offshoot of the British far-right political party UKIP, that was featured prominently in a now-deleted \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ChS3J893rpI\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eviral video\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e In 2018, a British court \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/5g-campaigner-trial-live-updates-15315540\" target=\"_blank\"\u003econvicted him\u003c/a\u003e for threatening two councilors in Gateshead. Steele is currently under an \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.gateshead.gov.uk/article/9699/Injunction-obtained-against-Gateshead-resident\" target=\"_blank\"\u003einjunction\u003c/a\u003e to prevent him from harassing or threatening the town's councilors or staff but \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/mark-steele-5g-gateshead-council-15269240\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewas allowed by the judge\u003c/a\u003e to continue speaking against 5G. \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/mark-steele-5g-gateshead-council-15269240\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eAccording to Chronicle Live\u003c/a\u003e, Steele denied that he was harassing council members, saying he \"acted proportionally.\"\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003e\u003cb\u003eThe Misquoted\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e[INSERT 15][INSERT 12]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName:\u003c/b\u003e Sen. Scott Jensen\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is:\u003c/b\u003e Jensen is a longtime family physician in Minnesota and a Republican member of the Minnesota Senate, who was elected in 2016. He is not seeking reelection in 2020 and is rumored to be interested in a run for governor.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the virus:\u003c/b\u003e On April 7, he gave a North Dakota TV \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://twitter.com/chrisbergpov/status/1247680994821509121\" target=\"_blank\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e in which he suggested that hospitals and physicians were being told by the CDC to list COVID-19 as the cause of death in cases where it might not be warranted. His comment that “Fear is a great way to control people” was picked up by InfoWars and QAnon supporters. He later appeared on Fox News and said hospitals get paid more if a patient is listed as having COVID-19 and is on a ventilator, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/04/24/fact-check-medicare-hospitals-paid-more-covid-19-patients-coronavirus/3000638001/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewhich is true\u003c/a\u003e. He did not directly say hospitals are doing this for the money, just that it’s a concern. His TV appearances were used in the “Plandemic” video, but he disavows virus conspiracies. \"I think that things are being taken out of context,” he \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.startribune.com/as-minnesota-senator-cast-doubt-on-covid-19-death-tolls-conspiracy-theorists-pounced-online/569785662/?refresh=true\" target=\"_blank\"\u003etold\u003c/a\u003e the Star Tribune.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said\u003c/b\u003e: Jensen is a physician in good standing.\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 13]\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eName\u003c/b\u003e: Dr. Cameron Kyle-Sidell\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWho he is\u003c/b\u003e: Kyle-Sidell is an emergency and critical care physician at Maimonides hospital in Brooklyn. In March and April, he worked in an intensive care unit dedicated to COVID-19 patients. He received his medical degree from Ben Gurion University of the Negev in Israel.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat he has said about the coronavirus:\u003c/b\u003e In a March 31 \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k9GYTc53r2o\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eYouTube video\u003c/a\u003e, he questioned whether putting COVID-19 patients on ventilators was the right protocol and worried that this “misguided treatment will lead to a tremendous amount of harm to a great number of people in a very short time.” Since he raised the issue, \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-ventilators-specia/special-report-as-virus-advances-doctors-rethink-rush-to-ventilate-idUSKCN2251PE\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eother physicians have shared similar views\u003c/a\u003e. But his opinion has been misstated by conspiracy theorists to imply that the virus is not what the medical establishment says it is. On May 10, he \u003ca rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://twitter.com/cameronks/status/1259466360691752961\" target=\"_blank\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e that he had not consented to being included in “Plandemic,” saying, “I do not believe the narrative underlying the origin or spread of this terrible disease is one of human ill intent. We are fighting a virus not each other.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat authorities have said:\u003c/b\u003e Kyle-Sidell is a doctor in good standing and his inclusion in “Plandemic” and other fringe narratives is the result of people misinterpreting or exaggerating his comments.\u003c/p\u003e[INSERT 2][INSERT 17]\u003cp\u003e\u003cbr
